maml:description.maml:para: Adds a printer to the specified computer.
The Add-Printer cmdlet adds a printer to a specified computer. You can add both local printers and connections to network-based printers.
You cannot use wildcard characters with Add-Printer. You can use Add-Printer in a Windows PowerShell remoting session.
You do not need administrative credentials to run Add-Printer.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the printer to add.
Specifies the name of the printer driver for the printer.

Specifies the maximum size, in megabytes, of the branch office remote offline log file for this printer. You cannot specify this parameter for unshared queues or queues that do not have branch office enabled.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the text to add to the Comment field for the specified printer.
Specifies the name of the computer to which to add the printer.
Specifies the data type the printer uses to record print jobs.
Indicates that branch office remote logging is disabled. You cannot specify this parameter for unshared queues.
Specifies whether the print jobs in the queue are kept.
Specifies the location of the printer.
Specifies the permissions for the printer as a Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) string.
Specifies the name of the port that is used or created for the printer.
Specifies the name of the print processor used by the printer.
Specifies the relative queue priority.
Specifies whether the printer is published in the network directory service.
Specifies the rendering mode for the printer. You can specify one of the following rendering modes:
-- SSR, Service Side Rendering
-- CSR.
Client Side Rendering -- BranchOffice. Branch Office
Specifies the path of and name of the separator page to be used by the printer.
Specifies the name by which to share the printer on the network. To share a printer, specify the Shared parameter.

Indicates whether to share the printer on the network. You can determine the name by which the printer is shared by specifying ShareName. If ShareName is not specified, the name of the printer is used as the share name.
Specifies the starting time of printer availability.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the ending time of printer availability.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the name of the printer to add.

Specifies the maximum size, in megabytes, of the branch office remote offline log file for this printer. You cannot specify this parameter for unshared queues or queues that do not have branch office enabled.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the name of the computer to which to add the printer.
Specifies the data type the printer uses to record print jobs.
Specifies a URL for directed discovery of Web Services on Devices (WSD) printer to add to the specified computer.
Specifies the multicast UUID for device detection for the WSD port.

Specifies whether the printer is published in the network directory service.

-- SSR, Service Side Rendering
-- CSR.
Client Side Rendering -- BranchOffice. Branch Office
Specifies the path of and name of the separator page to be used by the printer.
Specifies the name by which to share the printer on the network. To share a printer, specify the Shared parameter.

Indicates whether to share the printer on the network. You can determine the name by which the printer is shared by specifying ShareName. If ShareName is not specified, the name of the printer is used as the share name.
Specifies the starting time of printer availability.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the ending time of printer availability.

Specifies the name of a shared printer to which to connect. This parameter is required.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. -- CSR.

dev:type.maml:name: This cmdlet takes no input objects.

command:example.maml:title: --------- Example 1: Add a printer to a local computer ---------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Add-Printer -Name "mxdw 2" -DriverName "Microsoft XPS Document Writer v4" -PortName "portprompt:"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a printer with name mxdw2 to the local computer. The mxdw printer uses the Microsoft XPS Document Writer v4 driver and the portprompt: port.
The portprompt: port prompts for a file name to save the XPS document when printing to the XPS printer.

command:example.maml:title: ------- Example 2: Add a new network printer connection -------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a printer by specifying the name of a print server and a shared printer on that server.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves a list of print jobs in the specified printer.
The Get-PrintJob cmdlet retrieves the current print jobs in the specified printer. Specify the PrinterName parameter to list the print jobs from the specified printer.
You cannot use wildcard characters with Get-PrintJob. You can use Get-PrintJob in a Windows PowerShell remoting session.
You do not need administrator credentials to run Get-PrintJob.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the printer from which to retrieve the print job information.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the computer from which to retrieve the print job information.
Specifies the ID of the print job to retrieve. You can use wildcard characters.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the printer object from which to retrieve the print job information.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the ID of the print job to retrieve. You can use wildcard characters.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the computer from which to retrieve the print job information.
Specifies the ID of the print job to retrieve. You can use wildcard characters.
Specifies the name of the printer from which to retrieve the print job information.
Specifies the printer object from which to retrieve the print job information.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet accepts one printer object.
This cmdlet returns one or more print job objects.

command:example.maml:title: ------------- Example 1: Get a list of print jobs -------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves a list of print jobs on the printer named PrinterName.

command:example.maml:title: -- Example 2: Get a list of print jobs using a printer object --
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Printer = Get-Printer -Name "PrinterName:" PS C:\> Get-PrintJob -InputObject $Printer

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a printer named PrinterName: by using the Get-Printer cmdlet. The command stores the result in the $Printer variable.
The second command gets print jobs on the printer in $Printer.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a print job on the specified printer.
The Remove-PrintJob cmdlet removes a print job on the specified printer.
You can specify the print job to remove by specifying the PrinterName and job ID parameters, by specifying the printer object and job ID parameter, or by specifying a print job object as an input.
You cannot use wildcard characters with Remove-PrintJob. You can use Remove-PrintJob in a Windows PowerShell remoting session.
You do not need administrator credentials to run Remove-PrintJob.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies a printer name on which to remove the print job.
Specifies the ID of a print job to remove on the specified printer.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the computer on which to remove the print job.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the object which contains the printer on which to remove the print job.
Specifies the ID of a print job to remove on the specified printer.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the computer on which to remove the print job.
Specifies the ID of a print job to remove on the specified printer.
Specifies a printer name on which to remove the print job.
Specifies the object which contains the printer on which to remove the print job.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet accepts one print job object.

command:example.maml:title: ------------ Example 1: Remove a selected print job ------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the print job that has an ID of 1 on the printer named PrinterName.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Remove a print job using printer object and the print job ID
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Printer = Get-Printer -PrinterName "PrinterName" PS C:\> Remove-PrintJob -PrinterObject $Printer -ID "1"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the printer named PrinterName by using the Get-Printer cmdlet. The command stores the result in the $Printer variable.
The second command removes the print job that has an ID of 1 from the printer in $Printer.

command:example.maml:title: ---- Example 3: Remove a print job using a print job object ----
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $printJob = Get-PrintJob - PrinterName "PrinterName" -ID 1 PS C:\> Remove-PrintJob -InputObject $printJob

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a print job that has an ID of 1 on the printer named PrinterName by using the Get-PrintJob cmdlet. The command stores the job in the $PrintJob variable.
The second job removes the print job in $PrintJob.

maml:description.maml:para: Restarts a print job on the specified printer.
The Restart-PrintJob cmdlet restarts a print job on the specified printer.
You can specify the print job to restart by specifying the PrinterName and ID parameters, by specifying printer object and job ID parameter, or by specifying the job object as an input.
You cannot use wildcard characters with Restart-PrintJob. You can use Restart-PrintJob in a Windows PowerShell remoting session.
You do not need administrator credentials to use Restart-PrintJob.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the printer name on which to restart the print job.
Specifies the ID of the print job to restart on the specified printer. You can use wildcard characters.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the computer on which to restart the print job.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the printer object which contains the printer on which to restart the print job.
Specifies the ID of the print job to restart on the specified printer. You can use wildcard characters.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the computer on which to restart the print job.
Specifies the ID of the print job to restart on the specified printer. You can use wildcard characters.
Specifies the printer name on which to restart the print job.
Specifies the printer object which contains the printer on which to restart the print job.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet accepts one print job object.

command:example.maml:title: ----------- Example 1: Restart a selected print job -----------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command restarts the print job that has an ID of 1 on the printer named PrinterName.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Restart a print job by using printer object and the print job ID
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Printer = Get-Printer -PrinterName "PrinterName" PS C:\> Restart-PrintJob -PrinterObject $Printer -ID 1

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a printer named PrinterName by using the Get-Printer cmdlet. The command stores the result in the $Printer variable.
The second command restarts the print job that has the ID 1 on the printer in $Printer.

command:example.maml:title: -------- Example 3: Restart print job using job object --------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$PrintJob = Get-PrintJob -PrinterName "PrinterName" -ID 1 PS C:\> Restart-PrintJob -InputObject $PrintJob

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a printer job that has the ID on a printer named PrinterName by using the Get-PrintJob cmdlet. The command stores the result in the $PrintJob variable.
The second command restarts the print job in $PrintJob.

maml:description.maml:para: Resumes a suspended print job.
The Resume-PrintJob cmdlet resumes a suspended print job on the specified printer. The Resume-PrintJob cmdlet has no effect if any print job is running.
You can specify the print job to resume by specifying the PrinterName and ID parameters, by specifying the printer object and job ID parameter, or by specifying the print job object as an input.
You cannot use wildcard characters with Resume-PrintJob.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the ID of the print job to resume on the specified printer. You can use wildcard characters.
Specifies the name of the printer on which to resume the print job.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the computer on which to resume the print job.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the ID of the print job to resume on the specified printer. You can use wildcard characters.
Specifies the object which contains the printer on which to resume the print job.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the computer on which to resume the print job.
Specifies the ID of the print job to resume on the specified printer. You can use wildcard characters.
Specifies the name of the printer on which to resume the print job.
Specifies the object which contains the printer on which to resume the print job.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet accepts one print job object.

command:example.maml:title: ----------- Example 1: Resume a suspended print job -----------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command resumes the print job with an ID of 1, which was suspended on the printer named PrinterName.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Resume a print job using a printer object and job ID
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Printer = Get-Printer -PrinterName "PrinterName" PS C:\> Resume-PrintJob -PrinterObject $Printer -ID 1

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a printer named PrinterName by using the Get-Printer cmdlet. The command stores the result in the $Printer variable.
The second command resumes the print job that has the ID 1 on the printer in $Printer.

command:example.maml:title: ------- Example 3: Resume a print job using a job object -------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$PrintJob = Get-PrintJob - PrinterName "PrinterName" -ID 1 PS C:\> Resume-PrintJob -InputObject $PrintJob

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a printer job that has the ID on a printer named PrinterName by using the Get-PrintJob cmdlet. The command stores the result in the $PrintJob variable.
The second command resumes the print job in $PrintJob.

maml:description.maml:para: Suspends a print job on the specified printer.
The Suspend-PrintJob cmdlet suspends a print job on the specified printer. Use the Resume-PrintJob cmdlet to resume the suspended print job.
You can specify the print job to suspend by specifying the PrinterName and job ID parameters, specifying a printer object and the job ID parameter, or by specifying a print job object as an input.
You cannot use wildcard characters with Suspend-PrintJob. You can use Suspend-PrintJob in a Windows PowerShell remoting session.
You do not need administrator credentials to run Suspend-PrintJob.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies a printer name on which to suspend the print job.
Specifies the ID of the print job to suspend on the specified printer. You can use wildcard characters.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the computer on which to suspend a print job.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

Specifies the object which contains the printer on which to suspend the print job.
Specifies the ID of the print job to suspend on the specified printer. You can use wildcard characters.

Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

Specifies the name of the computer on which to suspend a print job.
Specifies the ID of the print job to suspend on the specified printer. You can use wildcard characters.
Specifies a printer name on which to suspend the print job.
Specifies the object which contains the printer on which to suspend the print job.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet accepts one print job object.

command:example.maml:title: ----------- Example 1: Suspend a specific print job -----------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command suspends the print job that has an ID of 1 on the printer named PrinterName.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Suspend a print job using a printer object and print job ID
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Printer = Get-Printer -Name "PrinterName" PS C:\> Suspend-PrintJob -PrinterObject $Printer -ID 1

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a printer named PrinterName by using the Get-Printer cmdlet. The command stores the result in the $Printer variable.
The second command suspends the print job that an ID of 1 on the printer stored in $Printer.

command:example.maml:title: --- Example 3: Suspend a print job using a print job object ---
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$PrintJob = Get-PrintJob -PrinterName "PrinterName" -ID 1 PS C:\> Suspend-PrintJob -InputObject $printJob

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a print job that has the ID 1 on the printer named PrinterName by using the Get-PrintJob. The command stores the result in the $PrintJob variable.
The second command suspends the print job in $PrintJob.
